output.rationale: This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (along with PM10) exposure and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is a time-series approach. The study reports quantitative associations including significant effects and risk estimates for asthma and COPD hospitalizations. Although the abstract doesn't explicitly state confidence intervals, it mentions statistically significant effects and uses standard epidemiological modeling that produces effect estimates. The focus on COVID-19 period comparison is a contextual factor but doesn't change the core study design.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (asthma exacerbations). The study uses time-series methodology (mixed-effects quasi-Poisson regression with daily data). While the abstract does not explicitly report RR/OR values, it reports a statistically significant association (P<10-4) and provides quantitative information (PM2.5 concentration at half maximum effect: 13.5 µg/m3), suggesting effect estimates are available in the full text. Asthma exacerbations requiring ED visits are a respiratory outcome meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined, (3) the outcome is asthma hospitalization which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) the study design is explicitly stated as case-crossover (time-stratified), (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), and (6) the article is published in English. Asthma hospitalization is a specific type of respiratory hospitalization and clearly fits the outcome criteria.

This is an original case-crossover study examining the association between air pollution (primarily PM2.5) and respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits for childhood asthma. While the primary exposure is AQI, the study specifically analyzes pollutant-specific effects and reports that PM2.5 was the primary pollutant (62% of days) and the association was strongest for PM2.5. The study reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for asthma exacerbations resulting in ED visits and hospitalizations, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a novel statistical approach; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory discharge diagnoses); (4) study design is case-crossover (time-stratified); (5) the abstract indicates associations/effect estimates were calculated for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes with statistical adjustment; (6) appears to be published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a major outcome of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with DLNM to assess PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospital admissions. It reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049 for PM2.5 at lag 07). The study appears to be published in English and provides quantitative effect estimates for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) outcome includes both emergency department presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis (a respiratory condition), (4) time-stratified case-crossover design is clearly stated, (5) odds ratios are reported with effect estimates (>10% increased risk for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. The fact that multiple pollutants (NO2, PM10, PM2.5) are studied does not exclude it, as PM2.5 is specifically analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) the study design is time-series, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092,1.0405), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is clearly one of the main exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) case-crossover design explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. While the population is specialized (childhood cancer survivors), this does not disqualify it from the review as it still examines the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), evaluates respiratory hospitalizations (bronchiolitis), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. The study is clearly published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original case-crossover epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes fine particulate matter (PM2.5), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children, (4) study design is case-crossover, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR 1.004 [0.955-1.056] and stratified estimates), and (6) published in English. The study also examines effect modification by particle constituents, which adds depth to the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization relationship.

While this is a time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations with reported RR estimates, the outcome is specifically COVID-19/SARS-CoV-2 hospitalizations rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome that differs from the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations typically examined in PM2.5 systematic reviews. The study meets most inclusion criteria but fails on the outcome criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) the outcome is respiratory emergency department visits (asthma ED visits), (4) it uses a time-series study design (quasi-Poisson log-linear time-series models), (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (rate ratios with 95% credible intervals), and (6) it is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes include both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports incidence rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., IRR 1.043, 95% CI: 1.000-1.089 for ED presentations), and (6) appears to be published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, (4) it uses a time-series study design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates including relative risk and percentage increases in hospitalization risk (e.g., 8.3% and 12.1% for temperature extremes, and mentions positive lag effects for PM2.5), and (6) the article appears to be published in English. Although the abstract focuses somewhat on temperature effects, PM2.5 is clearly one of the air pollutants analyzed with reported effects on respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with GAM, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports associations between PM2.5 and hospitalization risk with quantitative estimates mentioned in results, and (6) published in English. Although the abstract does not explicitly show the effect estimates with confidence intervals, it clearly states that PM2.5 exposures were associated with increased risks, indicating quantitative measures were calculated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5 from wildfire smoke; (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases); (4) uses case-crossover design; (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals; (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalization as a primary outcome.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (URTI) using a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson model with daily data). It reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%). Upper respiratory tract infections are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD, (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (asthma: 95% CI 0.981-1.148; COPD: 95% CI 0.966-1.019), and (6) published in English. Although the study found null results for PM2.5, it still provides quantitative effect estimates relevant to the systematic review.

While this study meets most inclusion criteria (PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization outcome, quantitative effect estimates with CI), it fails the study design criterion. The abstract explicitly describes this as a 'retrospective cohort study' rather than a time-series or case-crossover design. Although distributed lag models are used to analyze daily county-level rates (which has some time-series characteristics), the fundamental design is cohort-based with person-time follow-up, not the required time-series or case-crossover methodology.

While this is an original epidemiological study with a time-series design that reports effect estimates with confidence intervals and includes PM2.5 exposure, the primary outcomes are cardiovascular and cerebrovascular ED visits, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. Although respiratory conditions are mentioned as a secondary finding, the study's focus and design are centered on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes, making it inconsistent with the review's inclusion criteria.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (pneumonia, COPD/asthma). It uses a time-series design with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes including pneumonia. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory component.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and pneumonia hospitalizations (a respiratory outcome) with quantitative effect estimates, the study design is a prospective cohort rather than time-series or case-crossover as required by the inclusion criteria. The study follows 433,032 participants prospectively from 2015-2017, which is a cohort design approach, not the required analytical designs for this systematic review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models; (2) exposure is PM2.5 and source-specific PM2.5; (3) outcome is respiratory emergency room visits (ERVs); (4) study design is time-series (evidenced by lagged effects and use of GAM); (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR = 1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.020); (6) appears to be published in English. The study focuses on short-term associations between PM2.5 and respiratory emergency department visits, which aligns perfectly with the review objectives.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original case-crossover epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) as an exposure, respiratory hospital admissions as the outcome, reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage change in odds with 95% CI), and appears to be published in English. The study specifically reports that a 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 was associated with a 1.2% increase in odds of admission for respiratory diseases.

While this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure and quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with lung involvement, not a general respiratory hospitalization. The review targets respiratory hospitalizations (e.g., asthma, COPD, pneumonia, general respiratory infections), not hospitalizations for autoimmune diseases that happen to affect the lungs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory emergency department visits as the outcome (including asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, and upper respiratory infections), provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and is published in English in Environmental Health Perspectives.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports excess rates with confidence intervals (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%), and (6) appears to be in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

While the study examines PM2.5 exposure and uses an appropriate time-series design with generalized additive model, the outcome is outpatient visits for upper respiratory tract infections, not hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The title mentions 'hospitalization' but the abstract clearly describes 'outpatient visits' throughout, which are distinct from hospital admissions or ED visits required by the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using Poisson regression; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcomes include both respiratory ED visits and respiratory hospitalizations; (4) Study design is time-series (daily county-level counts linked with daily PM2.5); (5) Reports multiple RR estimates with 95% CIs (e.g., RR=1.25 [1.21, 1.30] for respiratory disease EDVs); (6) Published in English. The study examines both ED visits and hospitalizations for respiratory outcomes, making it highly relevant to the review.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations for AECOPD. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) for PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalization outcomes. Although the study focuses on interaction effects with temperature and includes multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) uses time-series regression design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI = 0.87, 2.35%), and (6) appears to be published in English. The study analyzes the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations using appropriate methodology.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (source-specific), reports respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits as outcomes, provides quantitative effect estimates (excess rates with 95% CIs), and appears to be published in English. The respiratory outcomes (influenza and pneumonia) are appropriate respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization/ED visits.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive model with quasi-Poisson regression to examine the association between PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (5.302% increase, 95% CI: 3.202, 7.445 for PM2.5 per 10 ug/m3 increase). While URTI is a specific type of respiratory condition, emergency department visits for URTI constitute respiratory ED visits, meeting the outcome criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (generalized additive model with lag structures) examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia and asthma). The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (2.22% increase per 10-unit increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%). The article appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is asthma emergency room admissions which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) time-series study design, (5) reports effect estimate of 7.2% increase with 95% CI 1.7-13.1%, and (6) appears to be published in English. The outcome specifically relates to respiratory hospitalization/ED visits for asthma.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures assessed; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ILD admissions are respiratory hospitalizations); (4) case-crossover design is specified; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported for multiple pollutants including PM2.5; (6) published in English. While the abstract primarily reports results for SO2 and NO2, PM2.5 was assessed as part of the study and interstitial lung diseases are respiratory conditions requiring hospitalization.

While this is a time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations and includes PM2.5 as an exposure variable, the abstract does not report any effect estimates (RR or OR) specifically for PM2.5. The results section only presents effect estimates for NO2, ozone, and noise, but not for PM2.5 or PM10, despite these being listed as exposure variables in the methods. Without a quantitative PM2.5 effect estimate with confidence interval, this study does not meet inclusion criterion 5.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and hospitalizations for COPD, which is a respiratory outcome. The study uses time-series methodology (generalized additive model with distributed lag models analyzing daily admissions). The abstract reports quantitative effect estimates (0.086-0.109% increases in daily admissions). While the abstract doesn't explicitly mention confidence intervals, the Results section indicates 'significant' findings, suggesting effect estimates with measures of uncertainty were calculated. COPD hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization that meets inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.73% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although PM2.5-10 is also included, PM2.5 results are separately reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using ecological time series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and asthma), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports relative risks with values (RR = 1.017, 1.022, 1.020 at different lags), and (6) published in English with bilingual abstract. The study uses appropriate GAM Poisson regression methodology and provides quantitative effect estimates for PM2.5 exposure on respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is original research on PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations in children, provides RR with 95% CI, and appears to be in English. However, the study design is described as a 'difference-in-differences approach generalized to multiple spatial units and time periods with distributed lag non-linear models' rather than explicitly as a time-series or case-crossover study. While it uses daily data and distributed lag models (typical of time-series), the difference-in-differences methodology is not a standard time-series or case-crossover design as specified in the inclusion criteria. The study design criterion is not clearly met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures examined, (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for respiratory diseases (COPD and upper respiratory diseases), (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) the abstract reports positive associations with specific lag periods indicating quantitative effect estimates were calculated, and (6) it is published in English. Although the abstract does not explicitly show RR/OR values with confidence intervals, it clearly states 'positive results were observed' for various pollutant-lag combinations, indicating that quantitative effect estimates with statistical significance were reported in the full paper.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute lower respiratory infections including pneumonia, COPD, bronchitis), (4) study design is explicitly stated as time-series, (5) reports percent increase in hospitalizations with 95% confidence intervals which can be converted to relative risks, and (6) published in English.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions for multiple disease categories including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., percent increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 with 95% CI). Although the study examines multiple organ systems, respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly included as one of the outcomes analyzed, making it relevant for the systematic review.

This is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (daily counts with generalized additive model of Poisson regression) examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency department visits for asthma. The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals. Although the study also examines PM2.5-bound PAHs, it explicitly analyzes PM2.5 as a separate exposure and reports effect estimates for PM2.5 specifically. Asthma emergency room visits are a respiratory outcome that meets inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as an exposure, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) uses a time-series design explicitly stated in title and abstract, (5) reports percentage change with 95% CI for PM2.5 (0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089% per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv), which are respiratory ED visits, (4) uses time-series approach as specified, (5) reports relative risk with specific quantitative estimates (RR increased by 4.4% per IQR increase in PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Though multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is clearly included with its own effect estimate.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and emergency department visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) uses case-crossover design with conditional logistic regression, (5) reports associations with 95% confidence intervals mentioned in the results, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and the inclusion criteria allow for PM2.5 to be one of multiple exposures.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model (GAM), which is characteristic of time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure; (3) respiratory hospitalizations are included as one of the outcomes examined; (4) the study design is time-series based on the GAM approach and analysis of daily data; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (1.03% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory HAs, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%); and (6) the article appears to be published in English. While the study examines multiple disease outcomes beyond respiratory conditions, respiratory hospitalization is a primary outcome analyzed.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) in relation to hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. The abstract mentions 'emergency admissions to hospital' and that 'secondary pollutants, especially nonprimary PM2.5, nitrate and sulfate, were more important for respiratory outcomes,' indicating respiratory hospitalizations were analyzed. The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. Although the results section primarily highlights cardiovascular outcomes, the methods clearly indicate respiratory admissions were examined and the conclusions reference findings for respiratory outcomes.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive models (GAMs) that examines PM2.5 exposure among other air pollutants. While the study examines multiple organ systems, it specifically reports results for respiratory system hospitalizations (NO2 effect: 1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%) and PM2.5 effects on various outcomes including respiratory. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals and meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with Poisson regression; examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10); assesses respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma exacerbations; reports relative risk estimates with confidence intervals (RR=1.24, 1.12, 1.31 for various lag periods); and appears to be published in English. All six inclusion criteria are satisfied.

Although this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits with effect estimates reported, and PM2.5 was controlled for in the analysis, the primary exposures of interest are precipitation and temperature on thunderstorm days, not PM2.5. The results explicitly state that PM2.5 levels were not significantly associated with asthma ED visits. PM2.5 was included only as a confounder/control variable, not as the exposure being investigated for association with respiratory outcomes.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series generalized additive model, (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (ALRI including pneumonia and bronchitis), (4) the study design is explicitly time-series, (5) relative risks with 95% confidence intervals are reported for PM2.5 (RR=1.0064, 95% CI 1.0004-1.0124 for pneumonia at lag4; RR=1.0133, 95% CI 1.0025-1.0242 for bronchitis at lag010), and (6) the abstract is in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure includes PM2.5 among other pollutants, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations for asthma and COPD, (4) uses case-crossover design which is specified in inclusion criteria, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 exposure, and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using Poisson regression models on daily hospital admission counts, indicating a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures; (3) Respiratory hospital admissions are a primary outcome; (4) The study design is time-series based on daily counts and lagged exposures; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported (pooled relative risk of 7.5% [4.9-10.2%] for respiratory admissions per 12.4 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 with 95% CI); (6) Published in English. While the study also examines ultrafine particles, PM2.5 is analyzed separately with specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with multi-level Poisson regression; exposure is PM2.5; outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; quantitative effect estimates are reported (percentage increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 for different racial/ethnic groups); and it appears to be published in English. The study provides specific effect estimates (8.6% for Black individuals, 6.2% for White individuals, 4.1% overall).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations, (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.74% increase per 10-μg/m3, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07% for respiratory admissions), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 as the exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome (159,365 respiratory disease admissions), provides quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (1.95% increase, 95% CI 1.63-2.27% per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5 increase for respiratory diseases), and appears to be published in English.

While this is a time-series study that includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and reports effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP), not PM2.5 mass concentration. The study specifically investigates whether the oxidative capacity of particles is associated with health outcomes, rather than examining PM2.5 exposure itself. Although PM2.5 was collected and used to derive OP measures, the exposure variable analyzed is OP (% loss per m³), not PM2.5 concentration.

This is an original epidemiological study examining fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma in Atlanta (2002-2010). The study uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models and reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals. While the study focuses on source apportionment of PM2.5, the exposure is still PM2.5 components, the outcome is respiratory ED visits (asthma), and quantitative effect estimates are provided. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using GAM for time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure, (3) respiratory disease hospitalization is the outcome, (4) the study design appears to be time-series based on the use of GAM to estimate short-term effects, (5) quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported (e.g., 1.95% increase with 95% CI: 0.25, 3.67 per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and (6) the article is in English. The study also examines PM10 but PM2.5 is one of the primary exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (specifically asthma), reports relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and appears to be published in English. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it explicitly includes respiratory hospitalizations including asthma as an outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations, (4) time-series design clearly stated, (5) reports excess risk percentages with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%-3.74%), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 exposure explicitly studied, (3) respiratory healthcare visits as outcome, (4) case-crossover design with time-stratified approach, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates (increases of 1 µg/m3 PM2.5 associated with increased odds), and (6) published in English. While the abstract doesn't explicitly mention confidence intervals, the study clearly reports quantitative associations and appears to be a rigorous epidemiological analysis.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of the exposures, (3) the outcome is hospitalization for respiratory diseases, (4) it uses a case-crossover study design, (5) it reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5), and (6) the abstract is in English. The study includes multiple pollutants but PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (along with aeroallergens) as an exposure and asthma exacerbation leading to ED and inpatient visits as outcomes. The study reports rate ratios with confidence intervals. Although the primary focus is on effect modification by viral infections and PM2.5 results are mentioned as negative findings, the study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure assessed, respiratory hospitalization/ED visits as outcomes, time-series design, and quantitative effect estimates reported.

This study meets the key inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model (GAM), which is standard for time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined; (3) the outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (patients with respiratory diseases and diabetes mellitus comorbidity); (4) the use of daily data and GAM indicates a time-series design; (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (7.25% increase per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5); and (6) the article appears to be in English. While the population is restricted to those with diabetes comorbidity, they still represent respiratory hospitalizations, which meets the outcome criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with reported effect estimates, the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which typically refers to infections of the upper respiratory tract (common cold, pharyngitis, etc.) rather than the lower respiratory tract conditions (pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, asthma) that are the typical focus of respiratory hospitalization studies. Upper respiratory tract infections are generally less severe and the clinical and public health implications differ from lower respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency department visits for asthma, uses generalized additive models, and reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals. The outcome is respiratory ED visits (asthma), which qualifies as respiratory emergency care.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study analyzing data from 249 Korean communities; (2) Exposure is clearly PM2.5; (3) Outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations; (4) Study design is case time series (a variant of time-series analysis); (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.43% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5); (6) Published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it explicitly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a primary outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (COPD admissions) as the outcome, provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (1.6% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7%), and appears to be published in English.

While this study examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures, uses a case-crossover design, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than hospitalization or ED visit specifically. The results section explicitly states 'We observed no such associations with...fine particles (≤2.5μm)', indicating no significant association between PM2.5 and the outcome. The primary focus is on ultrafine particles, not PM2.5.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design is specified, (5) the abstract indicates effect estimates were computed showing 'adverse relationships' and mentions effect strength with significance testing, suggesting quantitative measures are reported, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 is specifically mentioned and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study comparing PM2.5 exposure metrics, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is COPD hospitalizations (respiratory hospitalization), (4) uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.26, 95%CI: 1.06-1.50), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 and hospital admissions in Chinese cities, (2) Exposure includes PM2.5, (3) Outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (916,388 respiratory admissions identified), (4) Case-crossover study design as stated in title and methods (conditional logistic regression), (5) Reports effect estimates with 95% CIs (e.g., 0.26% increase in respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ PM2.5 increase with 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31%), (6) Published in English. All inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model, which is characteristic of time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure variable; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospital admissions for asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis; (4) Study design is time-series based on the methods described (daily hospital admissions data with control for trend, seasonality, weather); (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations; (6) Published in English. Although multiple air pollutants were examined, PM2.5 results are specifically reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is hospital admissions for pneumonia which is a respiratory hospitalization, (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals (12% increase with 95% CI and 4% increase with 95% CI), and (6) published in English.

The study focuses on coarse particles (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. While PM2.5 is mentioned in the abstract as an adjustment variable, the main exposure of interest is coarse particulate matter. This does not meet inclusion criterion #2 which requires PM2.5 as the exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is analyzed as one of multiple exposures with specific effect estimates reported; (3) outcome is hospital admissions for asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) time-series study design explicitly stated; (5) reports relative risk (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028) for PM2.5 per 10 μg/m3 increase; (6) appears to be published in English. The study focuses on asthma, which is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study; (2) Exposure includes PM2.5 (analyzed alongside PM10); (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for COPD exacerbation; (4) Time-series design with Poisson regression; (5) Reports RR with specific values for PM2.5 (e.g., RR=1.08 for ED admissions, RR=1.10 for hospitalizations at lag0-1); (6) Published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory condition requiring hospitalization/ED visit, which directly fits the review scope.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using CDC data; (2) Includes PM2.5 as exposure (alongside ozone); (3) Outcome is respiratory ED visits; (4) Time-series design explicitly stated; (5) Reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals for PM2.5 effects; (6) Published in English. Although it also examines ozone, PM2.5 is analyzed separately with quantitative effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study; (2) exposure is PM2.5 from specific sources; (3) outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits; (4) uses case-crossover study design; (5) reports excess risk (equivalent to relative risk) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes; (6) published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but since respiratory ED visits are analyzed and reported, it qualifies for inclusion.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The study uses generalized additive models, reports effect estimates (attributable risks mentioned), and asthma hospitalizations are a respiratory outcome. PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned in the results as one of the pollutants analyzed. Meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design with distributed lag non-linear models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) Outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) Study design is time-series regression; (5) Reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) Published in English. Although multiple pollutants were studied, PM2.5 results are clearly reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures; (3) The outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) The study uses a time-series design with generalized additive models; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5 with 95% CI 0.21-2.26%); (6) The article appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design, examines PM2.5 as one of multiple air pollutants, assesses emergency department visits for asthma (a respiratory outcome), and reports rate ratios (RRs) as effect estimates. The study is published in English and provides quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals.

The study includes PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as one of multiple exposures and examines respiratory hospitalizations using a time-series design (generalized additive Poisson regression with lags). However, the abstract primarily reports results for temperature effects only (18% increase in risk for 4°C increase in minimum temperature) and does not present specific effect estimates for PM2.5. The abstract states that one model 'included the pollutant' but provides no quantitative results for PM2.5's association with respiratory hospitalizations. Without confirmation that PM2.5 effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported in the full text, inclusion is uncertain.

This is an original time-series study examining the association between PM2.5 (and ozone) and cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative risk ratios (e.g., respiratory disease-ozone association RR=1.020 for ED visits and 1.004 for hospitalizations through ED). While the primary focus is comparing different visit types, it meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure explicitly mentioned, respiratory outcomes included, time-series design, and effect estimates with implied precision reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using case time series design; (2) Exposure is PM2.5; (3) Outcomes include both respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (4) Case time series is an appropriate study design for this review; (5) Reports excess relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (1.34% for respiratory ED visits); (6) Published in English. The study examines multiple outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design; (2) PM2.5 is included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) outcome is hospital admission for COPD exacerbations, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) study design is case-crossover with time-series analysis; (5) reports rate ratios with 95% CIs (RR=1.030, 95% CI: 1.006-1.055 for PM2.5); (6) published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (among other outcomes). The study explicitly reports associations with respiratory hospital admissions, uses a time-series design with distributed lag models, and reports quantitative effect estimates. Although it also examines cardiovascular admissions, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using generalized additive models with distributed lag models, which is consistent with time-series methodology; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) the outcome is emergency department visits for pediatric asthma, which is a respiratory ED visit; (4) the study design is time-series based on the methodology described (daily ED visits with GAM); (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.011, 95%CI: 1.002, 1.021 for PM2.5); and (6) the article is in English. Although the study examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is one of them with specific effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series analysis and case-crossover design as indicated in the title; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure; (3) outcome is hospital admission due to asthma, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) study design is time-series with case-crossover methodology; (5) reports rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3); (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is among them with specific effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI including pneumonia and bronchiolitis), (4) it uses a time-series design, (5) it reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075, 1.103 for PM2.5), and (6) appears to be published in English.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (as part of cardiopulmonary outcomes). The study uses Poisson regression with time-series design (county-specific effects across days with lag analysis, adjusted for temporal variables). The study reports percentage increases with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory and asthma-related hospitalizations, which are equivalent to effect estimates. All inclusion criteria are met.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and pediatric respiratory emergency room admissions. Although the study found no significant association with PM2.5, it meets all inclusion criteria: it's an epidemiological time-series study using generalized linear Poisson regression, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory ER visits as outcome, and provides effect estimates with 95% CIs. Null findings are still valuable for systematic reviews.

While this is an interrupted time series study that uses PM2.5 exposure estimates and examines respiratory hospitalizations among other outcomes, it examines long-term effects (8 years post-fire) rather than the typical short-term associations studied in time-series analyses. The study design is interrupted time series examining post-disaster effects rather than the day-to-day or short-term temporal associations between PM2.5 and hospitalizations that are the focus of standard time-series studies. Additionally, the abstract does not clearly indicate that stratified effect estimates with confidence intervals are reported specifically for the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original 18-year time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (including speciated organic carbon fraction) exposure in relation to respiratory ED visits (bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, URI) among children. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 4% increase for URI, 8% increase for pneumonia). Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures.

While this is an original time-series study with effect estimates, it fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, (2) the outcome is pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis (cardiovascular/thrombotic conditions), not respiratory hospitalizations. Pulmonary embolism, despite affecting the lungs, is a thrombotic cardiovascular condition, not a respiratory disease.

The study examines suicide deaths as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure and outcome inclusion criteria.

This is a critical review of PM10-mortality studies, not an original epidemiological study. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not original research, (2) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5, and (3) the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review/literature review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is coronary/cardiovascular disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The exposure includes PM10 but not specifically PM2.5.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) that examines mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) and focuses on PM10 rather than PM2.5. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: it is a review/meta-analysis rather than an original study, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, and the particulate matter exposure is PM10 not PM2.5.

The study examines out-of-hospital cardiac arrests (OHCAs) of cardiac origin as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While it meets criteria for exposure (PM2.5), study design (case-crossover), and effect estimates (odds ratios with 95% CI), the outcome is cardiovascular, not respiratory, making it ineligible for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is an animal study (mice) investigating the molecular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced lung injury and the protective effects of a pharmacological intervention (Astragaloside IV). It is not an epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits in human populations. The study design is an experimental animal model, not a time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report relative risks or odds ratios for hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('this review is focused on these aspects'), not an original epidemiological study. It discusses historical backgrounds, physicochemical characteristics, and pathological mechanisms of PM. While it mentions PM2.5 and respiratory diseases, it does not report original data or specific effect estimates from a time-series or case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) exposure, not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria. While the outcome (respiratory hospitalizations for COPD and asthma) and study design (time-series) meet the criteria, the exposure measure does not match the review requirements for PM2.5 specifically.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis component that meets several inclusion criteria (PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, likely reports effect estimates), the outcome is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The abstract explicitly states 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the outcome measure.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as required by inclusion criteria. While the study uses appropriate time-series design with Poisson regression, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, and includes hospital admissions as an outcome, the exposure does not match the specified criteria for PM2.5.

While this is an original case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) and NO2, not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm). The study does not mention PM2.5 as one of the exposures analyzed, which is a requirement for inclusion.

The study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) as the exposure variable, not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm). While this is an original time-series epidemiological study examining respiratory hospitalizations with reported relative risks and confidence intervals, it does not meet the exposure criterion of PM2.5. The inclusion criteria specifically require PM2.5 or fine particulate matter (≤2.5 μm), and PM10 represents coarse particulate matter which is a different exposure category.

This appears to be a health impact assessment or policy evaluation study rather than an original epidemiological study. The authors state they conducted 'a literature review to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and then 'calculated' public health gains based on selected relative risks from other studies. This indicates they are applying existing effect estimates to quantify potential benefits of meeting air quality standards, not conducting an original time-series or case-crossover analysis to derive new effect estimates from the PM2.5-hospitalization relationship.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the primary outcome and reported effect estimates are for ambulance dispatches generally, not specifically for respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with a case-crossover design that examines PM2.5 exposure and reports RR with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This fails to meet the inclusion criteria for outcome.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and cardiovascular events (not respiratory hospitalizations). The outcome is cardiovascular emergency department presentations (ICD-9: 390-459), which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

The study examines cardiovascular mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While the exposure includes air pollutants and uses a time-series design with distributed lag models, it does not meet the outcome criteria for this systematic review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), as evidenced by the methods describing inclusion of 196 articles in quantitative analysis, pooled relative risk estimates, heterogeneity assessment, and PROSPERO registration. The outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is a review/book chapter that summarizes existing literature rather than an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

While this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is myocardial infarction mortality (cardiovascular), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a review on respiratory hospitalizations.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 as an exposure and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization (cardiovascular), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 (coarse particulate matter) from mineral dust, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). The outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. These fail to meet the inclusion criteria for both exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (hospitalization/ED visit).

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series analysis to examine respiratory hospital visits with reported effect estimates, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study evaluates the effect of a burning ban intervention rather than directly examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. PM2.5 is not mentioned anywhere in the abstract.

The study examines the association between coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5) exposure and ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not respiratory hospitalizations. The outcome (ischemic stroke) does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study examines mortality (death) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Although it uses a time-series design, includes PM2.5 exposure, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the outcome criterion of respiratory hospitalization/ED visit.

This is a systematic review/meta-analysis paper, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the review mentions that some included studies examined PM2.5 exposure, this paper itself is a synthesis of other studies rather than primary research.

Study fails to meet inclusion criteria on two critical points: (1) Exposure is PM10, not PM2.5 (particulate matter ≤10 µm vs ≤2.5 µm), and (2) Outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While the study uses appropriate time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not match the specific exposure and outcome required for this systematic review.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). Two critical inclusion criteria are not met: the exposure is PM10 rather than PM2.5, and the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and uses years of life lost (YLL) from mortality data as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study design is time-series but does not meet the exposure or outcome inclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion requires original studies, and the exclusion criteria specifically exclude meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcomes focus on mortality (non-accidental, respiratory, cardiovascular) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

The study examines PM10 and NO2 exposure, not PM2.5. While the study includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, uses appropriate study designs (Poisson regression/time-series and case-crossover), and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the critical inclusion criterion of PM2.5 exposure. PM10 refers to particles ≤10 µm, which is a different exposure category than PM2.5 (≤2.5 µm).

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter <10 μm), not PM2.5 (particulate matter ≤2.5 μm) as required by the inclusion criteria. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Although the study design is case-crossover and reports effect estimates, it fails to meet the key exposure and outcome criteria.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as outcome. Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome measure.

While this is an original time-series study with effect estimates, it fails two critical inclusion criteria: (1) The exposure is PM10, NO2, and SO2, but NOT PM2.5, and (2) the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study examines mortality rather than hospital admissions.

This study focuses on coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Fails to meet both the exposure criterion (requires PM2.5) and outcome criterion (requires respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits).

This study examines respiratory mortality (deaths) as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While it is a time-series study with quantitative effect estimates and mentions respiratory mortality (RM) as one outcome, the review specifically requires respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, not mortality outcomes.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (particulate matter <10 µm), not PM2.5 (≤2.5 µm). While the study design is case-crossover and reports effect estimates, it does not meet the critical inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and mortality outcomes (not hospitalization or ED visits). The study does not meet the inclusion criteria for exposure type (requires PM2.5) or outcome (requires respiratory hospitalization/ED visit, not mortality).

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and cardiovascular/coronary heart disease hospitalizations (not respiratory hospitalizations). It fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

The study outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on economic losses due to mortality rather than hospital admissions. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome of interest.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10), not PM2.5 as required. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study design is appropriate (time-series) and effect estimates are provided, but it fails to meet the exposure and outcome criteria.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure and case-crossover design with effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory/thoracic cancer), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study does not meet the outcome inclusion criterion.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. These violate inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with effect estimates reported, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on years of life lost (YLL) and mortality counts from various causes including respiratory diseases, but does not assess hospital admissions or ED visits.

Although this is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design with PM2.5 exposure and effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause and specific-cause including respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study does not meet inclusion criterion 3.

The outcome is mortality (all-cause mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Although the study meets criteria for exposure (PM2.5), study design (time-series and case-crossover), and reports effect estimates, it does not meet the outcome requirement for this systematic review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Exclusion criteria explicitly state that reviews and meta-analyses should be excluded. While the reviewed studies may have examined PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes, this publication itself is a synthesis of existing literature rather than original research.

The study examines respiratory mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The systematic review specifically requires hospitalization or ED visit outcomes, but this study only reports mortality data.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Although the study meets other criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals), the outcome does not match the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the underlying studies may have examined PM2.5 and respiratory morbidity using appropriate designs, this publication itself is a review article synthesizing other studies.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates and confidence intervals, the outcome is respiratory MORTALITY, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study reports respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be an overview/report of multiple integrated studies (NPACT Initiative) rather than a single original epidemiological study. While it mentions a time-series study (Ito study) examining morbidity and mortality, the abstract describes four different studies including animal toxicology studies and in vitro studies. The outcomes mentioned are general 'morbidity and mortality' and 'annual mortality' rather than specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Without access to individual component studies and unclear if respiratory-specific outcomes were reported with effect estimates, this integrated research program report does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a methodological comparison study (meta-analysis vs pooled analysis) rather than an original epidemiological study. The outcomes examined are mortality (deaths due to natural causes, cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease, and respiratory disease), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study does not present original effect estimates for PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines ozone exposure as the primary exposure (not PM2.5) and measures mortality as the outcome (not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits). While the study design is time-series and includes effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the critical inclusion criteria for exposure (PM2.5) and outcome (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While it is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome (respiratory and other causes of mortality) does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically require respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between air pollution and heart failure (cardiovascular outcome), not respiratory hospitalization. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria for a review focused on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('have been described in this review') discussing mechanisms and causal associations between PM2.5 and health. It is not an original epidemiological study and does not report primary data on respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates from a time-series or case-crossover design.

This is explicitly described as a review ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence...') and not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from multiple studies rather than reporting original data. Additionally, the outcome focuses on prenatal exposure effects and birth outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, and it does not report original effect estimates.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes 364 other articles. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic diseases (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS, migraine) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria #1 (not original research) and #3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The title explicitly states it is a 'systematic review and meta-analysis' and the abstract describes pooling effect estimates from 145 studies identified through systematic search. This violates inclusion criterion 1 and meets the first exclusion criterion.

This is explicitly stated as a review article focusing on cellular mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cell death. It does not report original epidemiological data on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits, does not use time-series or case-crossover design, and does not report quantitative effect estimates for clinical outcomes.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not a respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not an original study) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the study examines PM2.5 exposure and includes hospital utilization as an outcome with effect estimates, it synthesizes data from multiple studies rather than reporting original research.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly identified as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes existing literature rather than reporting new primary data. This fails inclusion criterion #1.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article ('this review article was prepared', 'In this review, we focus on'), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is kidney disease/chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not original research) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes existing studies rather than reporting primary data. Additionally, the reported outcomes are respiratory and cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and the exclusion criteria explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses.
This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we discussed...'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are specifically excluded by the inclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study examining long-term exposure, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial discussing the general health effects of wildfire smoke and PM2.5. It does not present original epidemiological data, does not specify a study design (time-series or case-crossover), does not report quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, or CI), and does not focus specifically on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as an outcome measure. The text discusses general health impacts and policy implications rather than presenting results from an original research study.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we summarize...'), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome focuses on vascular endothelial cell toxicity and various diseases, not specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Reviews are explicitly excluded per the inclusion criteria.

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes existing evidence rather than an original epidemiological study. It explicitly states it used 'Cochrane rapid review methodology' and reviewed 450 manuscripts. Reviews are explicitly excluded per the exclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes results from 9 other studies. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is explicitly identified as a review article in the title ('A review of implications for human health'). It does not present original epidemiological data, does not report specific effect estimates with confidence intervals, and does not describe a time-series or case-crossover study design. The abstract discusses general health impacts of NH3 and PM2.5 but does not focus on respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as outcomes.

This is a review article (as stated in the abstract: 'This review summarizes and discusses studies...') focused on neurological outcomes (Alzheimer's disease and dementia) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: not an original study, wrong outcome, and is a review rather than primary research.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between particulate matter and myocardial infarction (cardiovascular outcome, not respiratory). Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not original study) and 3 (outcome is cardiovascular hospitalization, not respiratory).

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) and focuses on ocular surface disease outcomes (conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, blepharitis) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.
